item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China’s Communist Party Plenum: What to Expect
item.description: Since what happens in China increasingly affects people across the globe, this Fifth Plenum of the 18th Central Committee of the Communist Party is a meeting worth watching.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping, center, and other Communist Party leaders voting during the Third Plenum of the 18th Central Committee in 2013. The Fifth Plenum takes place next week.

item.title: U.S. and Russia Find Common Goals on Syria, if Not on Assad
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry and Sergey V. Lavrov, his Russian counterpart, said they agreed that the Islamic State must be defeated and that talks were a positive sign.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW ROSENBERG and NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry, right, with his adviser, John Kirby, second from left, before a news conference in Vienna on Friday.

item.title: World Briefing: W.H.O. Panel Backs Polio Vaccine With Just 2 Strains
item.description: The scientists also recommended that infants as young as 6 months get measles vaccine when the risk of catching it is high.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: World Briefing: Libya: 6 Killed as Rockets Hit Protesters in Benghazi
item.description: The group had gathered to protest a United Nations proposal for a unity government to end a political crisis.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Hurricane Patricia Strikes Mexico With 165 M.P.H. Winds
item.description: Some of Mexico’s most popular resorts are in the path of the hurricane, which meteorologists called the strongest recorded in the Western Hemisphere.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN, AZAM AHMED and FRANCES ROBLES
item.media:description: Preparations were underway for the arrival of Hurricane Patricia in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, on Thursday.

item.title: Hurricane Patricia Live Coverage
item.description: The storm hit along the coast near the city of Cuixmala, 55 miles northwest of Manzanillo, according to the National Hurricane Center.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Open Source: Video of Turkish Fishermen Saving Migrant Baby From Sea
item.description: Dramatic video, posted online on Friday, showed a Turkish fishing boat saving a baby from drowning in the Aegean Sea this week.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: New Scrutiny on Vote Buying as Argentine Elections Near
item.description: The practice, which is not illegal, was called a scourge last month in local voting, but raises questions about the frailty of the nation’s democracy.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN GILBERT
item.media:description: A campaign poster for the front-runner in Sunday's presidential election, Daniel Scioli, in Buenos Aires. The practice of offering goods and services in exchange for votes, though legal, has been called into question as the election approaches.

item.title: Leading Malaria Vaccine Gets Mixed Reviews
item.description: Two respected medical voices urged caution on the leading candidate for a malaria vaccine, Mosquirix, while two other expert panels recommended going ahead with pilot projects.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: A child playing by her pregnant mother's bed in July 2014 in Kirando, Tanzania, as the mother was treated for malaria. Doctors Without Borders and a New England Journal of Medicine editorial raised concerns about a leading malaria vaccine candidate this week.

item.title: Xi Jinping’s Britain Visit Ends Amid Criticism of Arrest of Dissidents in London
item.description: Three demonstrators were arrested and Chinese dissidents accused the British police of unnecessary force as China’s president ended a successful visit with Britain’s prime minister.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: 43 Killed in Southwestern France as Bus and Truck Collide
item.description: The accident, near Bordeaux, was the country’s deadliest in 33 years, officials said. Most of the victims were retirees on an excursion that included a ham-tasting.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN and LILIA BLAISE

item.title: Suicide Attack Against Shiites Kills at Least 22 in Southern Pakistan
item.description: There were no immediate claims of responsibility, but Sunni insurgents are believed to be behind the bomb attack, which struck a Shiite procession.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Take a Number: 19,000: Birds for Sale in Jakarta’s Biggest Markets
item.description: Birds are widely sought as pets in Indonesia, and the demand is taking a toll on threatened species.
item.dc:creator: RACHEL NUWER
item.media:description: A salesmen and his birds in one of Jakarta's markets. Researchers warned that the trade in wild birds was driving some species to extinction.

item.title: Election in Tanzania to Challenge Half a Century of One-Party Rule
item.description: Voters in Tanzania, usually one of Africa’s most peaceful nations, will take part in the most heavily contested presidential vote in the nation’s history on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.media:description: Supporters of the governing Party of the Revolution in Tanzania on Friday. Many Tanzanians say that the party was good in the 1970s and 1980s, and for part of the ’90s, but that it has since lost its way.

item.title: Kosovo Lawmakers Flee Tear Gas as Opposition Protests EU-Brokered Accord
item.description: Opposition politicians in Kosovo released tear gas in Parliament to obstruct a scheduled session as police clashed with hundreds of protesters in Pristina streets.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS
item.media:description: Opposition lawmakers in Kosovo released tear gas in the Parliament building on Friday in Pristina, forcing their colleagues from the chamber.

item.title: As Poland Prepares to Vote, Its Gaze Drifts Toward the Right
item.description: Pre-election polls show the Law and Justice party ahead of the governing Civic Platform party, though perhaps not far enough ahead to win a parliamentary majority on its own.
item.dc:creator: RICK LYMAN
item.media:description: Beata Szydlo, right, the Law and Justice party’s candidate for prime minister, has campaigned, among other issues, against being forced by the European Union to accept a set number of the refugees who have been flooding into Europe.

item.title: Calls Grow at U.N. for Security Council to Do Its Job: Keep the Peace
item.description: Frustration is aimed at the five permanent members of the Security Council, which include Britain, China, France, Russia and the United States.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Sweden School Attack, Treated as a Hate Crime, Prompts Soul-Searching
item.description: A spokesman for the regional police said the nature of the attack, and evidence found in the suspect’s apartment, suggested that he was a right-wing extremist.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Obama’s Anti-ISIS Point Man Leaving as Russia Steps In
item.description: Gen. John R. Allen, who departs next month, created an international coalition to fight the Islamic State, but his plan did not foresee Russian intervention.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: South Africa Freezes Tuition Fees After Student Protests
item.description: “Government understands the difficulty faced by students from poor households,” President Jacob G. Zuma said, ceding to university students’ demands.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI
item.media:description: Protesters angry about planned tuition increases gathered in Pretoria, South Africa, on Friday.
